column2: Aarakocra are reclusive and usually peaceful avians, who usually keep to their mountain eyries. But a few have found success in the societies of other cultures.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Auran

Aasimar are the descendants of celestials and deities of the upper planes. Many are renowned for good deeds, but some rebel against their heritage and choose other paths.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Celestial
Abeiran cultures originate on Toril's twin world of Abeir, separated from in aeons ago. They share a history in having been subjugated by Primordials and dragons both.
Aberrations are creatures that are directly or indirectly the result of the influence of the Far Realm. They are often completely alien to all other forms of life and are difficult to comprehend.

Said to be an offshoot of the Baatezu, the Abishai are devils in the form of small dragons, originating on Avernus, the first layer Baator. They primarily serve Tiamat, Queen of Evil Dragons, but can also be found drafted into the Baatezu ranks of the Blood War.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Infernal

Aboleths are seemingly immortal fish-like beings with strange psychic powers and strange, alien agendas. They possess a form of genetic memory, in which an Aboleth inherits the memories of all their ancestors upon birth.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Abolethic
Abominations are among the strongest and most snake-like of the yuan-ti.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Yuan-ti

The Aevendrow, or Starlight Elves, are a rare drow group that lives mainly in secrecy in arctic regions of Faerûn, seeking an alternative to the wars and fanaticism that beset their kinfolk.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Drowic
The Affa people are the indigenous inhabitants of Afyal, the Isle of the Elephant. Their society is one of rigid castes, and forbids the harming of elephants.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Affa

Aglarondan culture emerged in the wake of the victory of the Yuirwood elves over Velprin. It is a hybrid culture, adhered to by many half-elves and shaped by the aggression of Thay.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Aglarondan
Air genasi, sometimes called windsouls, are people with ancestral ties to the Elemental Plane of Air, and its residents such as djinn.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Auran
The Akotans are a seafaring and mercantile culture that trades extensively with Zakhara, Arandron and Katashaka, acting as intermediaries between the southern continents.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Midani
The Amaese people live in the icy Ama Basin in the far north of Kara-Tur, eking out semi-nomadic lives within that harsh land.

Amethyst Dragons tend to be aloof philosophers who regard everyday moral problems as beneath their notice. They live in cool climates and can exhale a variety of weaponised forcefields.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Draconic

The Amnian culture is notoriously focused on mercantile pursuits and known for their open distrust of arcane magic. Amnian society is highly stratified, with the social castes being defined exclusively by how much money one has.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Thorass

Amphipteres are gigantic winged serpents similar to wyverns or green dragons. They are generally extremely rare, and their true origins are a matter of speculation among sages.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Draconic

The Amran people hail from the Sword Lands of eastern Laerakond, once united as the kingdom of Amra. Of all the regions of Laerakond, this region is among the most human-dominated, and the continent's notorious dragon rulers have historically avoided it out of fear.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Thorass

The inhabitants of the Farsea Marshes are descended from some of the few survivors of Anauria, one of the successor realms of Netheril and driven south by both the harshness of the Anauroch as well as goblinoid aggression. \n§ZCourt Language§!: Andt\n§Y*§! Can establish catoblepas ranches on marsh terrain provinces (title decision).
Aasimon are powerful celestials that are not tied to one specific outer plane, but can serve deities or other celestial groups as they see fit.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Celestial

One of the cultures of the Great Glacier, the Angulutiuns are traditionally nomadic caribou herders and strict followers of their unwritten customs.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Ulutiun\n§Y*§! Access to the Eldership succession.
Archons are celestials from the Seven Heavens of Mount Celestia, dedicated to Law and Good.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Celestial

Arctic Dwarves, or Inugaakalikurit, are an offshoot of the main dwarven race that are native to the isolated Great Glacier of the far north. Artic Dwarf society cared little for either clan lineages or crafstmanship, instead valuing the good of their community and a casual lifestyle.\n§Y*§! Can gain the Berserker trait.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Kurit
Ardlings are a kind of aasimar, descended from deities or celestials, and possessing diverse animal-like features.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Celestial

The Arkaiun people were once related to both the Nar and the Illuskans, arriving in southern Faerûn through a portal and then being pushed further south by the Shaaran tribes. They are expert horse breeders, with the animals having an important place in their culture.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Akalan, Dambrathan
The Arnadar people live around the shores of Arnaden, otherwise known as the Lake of Steam, and are closely related to the Calishites.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Alzhedo.
Avorals are an avian variety of Guardinal, celestials from the Blessed Fields of Elysium.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Celestial

Laerti, known to outsiders as Asabi, are desert-dwelling lizardfolk, well adapted to dry conditions such as those of Anauroch. They, like many other scaled ones, are creations of the ancient Sarrukh.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Draconic\n§Y*§! Can gain the Berserker trait.

A subgroup of Stone Giants, the Ash Giants were found only in Unther's Black Ash Plain. They live tribal lives, raiding for what their ashen homeland cannot provide.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Jotun, Jotunstein
The Aslanlar people, also known as the Lions of Arnaden, are nomads living in the inland territories north of the Lake of Steam.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Alzhedo\n§Y*§! Access to the Eldership succession

The Astok people are the indigenous inhabitants of the Furrowed Mountains of Zakhara. They are often hostile to all outsiders, a reaction to the frequent mamluk raiding parties from Qudra.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Midani
Native to the Astral Plane and travelling across myriad worlds in their spelljammers, the Astral Elves are more aloof and imperialistic than their land-bound kind.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Elvish
The Asuras are wild celestials who in ancient times quarelled with the Aasimon and went their own way, pursuing the cause of good solely by their own lights.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Celestial

Avariel, or aril-tel-quessir, are winged elves who survived near-extinction in ancient wars against dragons. Their society is split into two groups, the "peaceful" and the "warlike".\n§ZCourt Language§!: Elvish
The avian peoples of Faerûn are descended from the ancient Aearee creators, who vanished from Toril many ages ago.

The Azuposi are the inhabitants of the Pasocada Basin in Maztica, maintaining an agrarian and matrilineal society. They highly respect their elders, who in turn have great political and religious power.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Azuposi

The Baatezu, or Devils, are the inhabitants and master of the Nine Hells of Baator. They seek to impose their own cruel and merciless order upon the Planes, by both corrupting mortals as well as waging war against celestials and demons both.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Infernal

The Badia are nomads who live in the deserts of Zakhara, apart from the settled folk. Their wandering life across a harsh landscape has led them to value freedom over traditional wealth, and as such they consider themselves the richest in all of Zakhara.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Midani

Bakemono are goblinoids from Kara-Tur whose physical appearance varies wildly, though always short and misshapen. Though they live in tribes, individual bakemono have no loyalty to their group and might abandon their kin on the flimsiest of reasons.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Oni

Near the top of the abyssal hierarchy are the Balors, the living incarnations of the Abyss's fury. Thouh few in number, they are both incredibly powerful and are capable of uniting hordes of demons under their will.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Abyssal

Baphitaurs are abyssal planetouched minotaurs, created through magical experiments in ancient Netheril. Their mindsets are often not too dissimilar from that of demons, believing the strongest have the right to do as they will.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Abyssal

The Barovian people originated on an unknown world, but the majority of them have long been trapped in the Demiplane of Dread by the actions of their overlord, Strahd von Zarovich. Rarely, a few of them are able to travel to other worlds such as Toril, but all too often they can never fully escape the pull of their cursed homeland.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Balok

Bigger than a goblin, though not as much as other goblinoids, the Batiri are the native goblinoid of Chult. They are semi-nomadic and quite hostile to non-Batiri, although they show great restraint in any conflict against their fellows.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Batiri

The Batrachi are an ancient frog-like shapeshifting race that once dominated all of Abeir-Toril before being nearly wiped out through their own hubris and conflicts with giantkind.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Batrachi
The Bawani are a maritime people native to the island of Bawa, in the Celestial Sea east of Kara-Tur, who are renowned for their skill at woodwork.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Bawani
The Beastfolk of Toril are many and varied. Their origins are largely lost to history, and it may be that many of them lived in the wild parts of the land before modern humanoids displaced them.

The Bedine trace their ancestry to pre-Enlightenment Zakhara, but have lived as nomads in Anauroch for countless generations. They are a proud, patriarchal people and possess a great hatred of arcane magic.\n§Y*§! Access to the Eldership succession.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Midani

Beholders are many-eyed aberrations that each think of themselves as the perfect lifeform and ideal child of the Great Mother. They will sometimes cluster together in hives and can occasionally affect the reality around them through their dreams and delusions.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Quevquel
Black dragons typically live in swamps and can spit acid. They are notorious for short tempers and cruelty.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Draconic
Blights are a kind of intelligent plant life given mobility and motivation by destructive magic. They vary widely in size, and are generally unfriendly to strangers.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Sylvan
Blue dragons, also known as storm dragons for their lightning breath, typically live in harsh desert climates and have a reputation as manipulative tricksters.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Draconic
Bone nagas are nagas of other kinds which have been animated by necromantic magic after death.\n§ZCourt Language§! Yuan-ti, Draconic:

A melting pot culture of the Border Kingdoms, these people combine elements of the cultures of Tethyr, Calimshan, Chondath, and beyond, as they make their own paths in the volatile region.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Alzhedo, Chondathan

Brass dragons live in barren deserts, and love to converse at length with their infrequent intelligent guests. If need be, they can exhale a cloud of potent soporific gas.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Draconic

Bronze dragons dwell along exposed coastlines, but their varied breath weapons and powerful magical capabilities mean that they are often only encountered if they wish to be.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Draconic

Brown dragons, also called sand dragons, are voracious hunters that live in deserts and scrublands. They can spit acid, and although they are generally antisocial, they are sometimes venerated by smaller creatures living alongside them.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Draconic

The largest of the goblinoids, Bugbears are hairy and brutish goblinoids that nonetheless have an unnatural talent for stealth. In spite of their size or strength, they are notorious cowards and often cowed by other goblinoids.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Ghukliak\n§Y*§! Can gain the Berserker trait.

The Calishite culture has their origin in the Zakharan slaves of the genies Calim and Memnon and their courtiers. They are a proud and often arrogant people, believin themselves to be superior to all their neighbours. Due to their past history with genies, a large number of genasi can be found among them.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Alzhedo

The cultural history of Calimshan and its neighbours reaches back to old Coramshan and before, to the days of the genie empires of the Era of Skyfire. Many human and genasi cultures trace their ancestry to these civilisations and their successors in the Shoon Imperium.

The children of a mortal and a fiend of any kind is a cambion, or half-fiend. They are often influenced by their fiendish parent, but are not bound by their ascendancy.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Infernal, Abyssal

Celestial eladrin are immortal planar creatures from the Shining Mountains of Arvandor. They superficially resemble elves, but have powers and awareness far beyond all but the mightiest of elvenkind.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Celestial

Celestials, sometimes also called angels, are powerful planar beings from the upper outer planes. Many remain in those blessed regions, but others have missions or callings that bring them to the material plane.

The Han people were the ancestors of many seafaring cultures around the north and west of the Celestial Sea of Kara-Tur. Their descendants have explored and settled many of the archipelagos, and some have travelled throughout mainland Kara-Tur and Faerûn.

The creatures most often called centaurs, or more properly hippocentaurs, have the upper bodies of humans atop the shoulders and bodies of horses. They come in a range of sizes, and tend to live in plains and scattered forests where they can run free.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Kentaur
Centaurs are creatures characterised by humanoid torsos rising from the shoulders of animal bodies. Their cultures are varied, but tend to exist on the margins of other humanoid societies.
Cervidals are guardinals, celestials from the Blessed Fields of Elysium, who have the heads and hooves of goats. They are fierce defenders of the innocent.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Celestial

The Chessentans are a passionate people, bent on living life to the fullest. They can trace their origins to the ancient Untheric Empire, but have long since gained their independence. They fully embrace war and the heroes that arise from it, though they also highly value philosophy, acting and sports.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Chessentan
The Ch'ing are the native people of the Shou province of Ch'ing Tung. They are seen by their neighbours as adventurous and innovative, even to a fault.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Shou

The Chondathan people arose from the remnants of the fallen psionic empire of Jhaamdath. Though concentrated around the Vilhon Reach, they are known to travel far and are sometimes regarded as risk-takers.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Chondathan

The Chondathan cultures spread out around the Sea of Fallen Stars after the destruction of Jhaamdath by elven high magic. They are widely scattered now, which has led to the adoption of Chondathan languages as a form of the Common Tongue.
Chromatic Dragons are distinguished by the solid, non-reflective colour of their scales. They are the favoured children of the goddess Tiamat, and often reflect her evil nature.

The Chu are the people of the Shou province of Chu' Yuan, the Bamboo Plains. Their outlook has been shaped by generations of warfare between Shou Lung and the breakaway empire of T'u Lung, which have made them wary of outside influences.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Shou

The Chukien people are the inhabitants of the Shou province of Chukei, which was the heart of old Shou Lung. The prevalence of red and brown hair among the Chukien sets them apart from their neighbours.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Shou

The human Chultan people, sometimes also sharing the name Tabaxi with the famed catfolk, originated in Katashaka in very distant times. They were led to safety in Chult by coatls who introduced them to the benevolent primordial Ubtao.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Tabaxi

The albino Chultan Dwarves, as distinct from their neighbours the Wild Dwarves, live in an underground realm known as the Domain, and support themselves with trade and mining.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Shanatan, Authalan\n§Y*§! Can gain the Berserker trait.

The Chun cultures were a diverse range of civilisations in eastern and central Zakhara before the time of the First Caliph, united by their common Chun language. Since then, they have largely been eclipsed by the Badia and Hadhar.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Chun

The cloud giants, or Skyejotunen, are giants who typically make their homes on high mountain-tops or in enchanged cloud castles. They often live lives of luxury, creating and collecting works of art.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Jotun, Jotunskye
The Commani are one of the western nomadic peoples from the Endless Wastes, and are regular raiders of their neighbours.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Commani\n§Y*§! Access to the Ultimogeniture succession.
Constructs are synthetic life-forms, some made by mortal artifice and others by the power of the gods and the outer planes.
Copper dragons usually dwell in dry upland areas, and have a reputation as pranksters and patrons of the arts.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Draconic

Corbies, sometimes known as Dire Corbies, are a culture of humanoid birds similarly to tengu. They live primarily in the Underdark, but can be found elsewhere as well. They are regarded by their peers as sneaky, but nonetheless fearsome in combat.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Corby-song

The Cormyrean people are a largely human culture based in the Forest Kingdom of Cormyr, which was settled by pioneers from Impiltur and Chondath in the years just after the raising of the Standing Stone in neighbouring Cormanthyr.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Chondathan

Cornugons, or horned devils, are commonly junior officers in the Blood War armies of the baatezu, directing companies of lesser fiends and conscripted mortals under the orders of pit fiends.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Infernal

The Crinti are largely half-drow, the descendants of human priestesses of Loviatar and drow from T'lindhet who allied to defeat the Arkaiuns and gain ascendancy over Dambrath.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Dambrathan\n§Y*§! Access to the Tanistry succession.

Crystal dragons commonly live in icefields or on frozen mountain-tops, but are said to love the company of other creatures and to travel far in order to socialise and exercise their curiosity.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Draconic

The Dalat are the southernmost of the peoples of the Endless Wastes. Their language is an offshoot of that of Semphar, and they're often confused for the Tuigan by westerners.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Dalat\n§Y*§! Access to the Ultimogeniture succession.

The Dalesfolk are the inhabitants of the Dalelands, whose forebears gained the right to settle in the open spaces among the forests of Cormanthyr by treaty with the elves, and raised the Standing Stone to mark this pact in 1 DR, the Year of Sunrise.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Chondathan

The Damaran people are largely descended from the humans of Low Netheril, along with those from what was once Jhaamdath and the dwarves of Tethyamar. They mainly dwell in the cold lands of Damara and the Bloodstone Lands, but also spread into neighbouring regions.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Damaran

Many peoples are descended from the humans of Low Netheril, who scattered eastward to the lands around Damara when the archwizard Karsus destroyed High Netheril in his hubris and later intermingled with the peoples of East Faerûn.

Dao are the genies of Elemental Earth, who generally view all non-Dao as inferiors worthy only of contempt and servitude. In their home plane, they are the rulers of a great slaving empire led by a Great Khan.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Terran

The modern dark elves arise from magical attempts to reverse the sun elf curse and restore to the drow the peaceful life that was stolen from them by the spiteful plots of the goddess Llolth.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Elvish

The dark elves, in the broad sense, include all the descendants of the elves of ancient Ilythiir and Miyeritar, which were destroyed in the Crown Wars millennia ago. Many of them were cursed by the victorious sun elves, and driven into the Underdark where they were known as drow.

Deep dragons, also called purple dragons, are slender, serpentine creatures which live in remote parts of the Underdark. They are often proud, and love to demonstrate their superior skills and knowledge to others.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Draconic

The Deep Imaskari people were the descendants of suvivors of the fall of ancient Imaskar to the Mulan people and the monstrous Phaerimm. They lived in underground enclaves for centuries before starting to emerge into Faerûn once more.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Roushoum

Dekanter goblins were once normal goblins before being mutated by the Beast Lord, an alhoon, into their current form. They are much larger than regular goblins, sport a rhinoceros-like snout and possess a culture more akin to mountain orcs than to their goblin forebears.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Ghukliak

The Derro are a secretive community of subterranean dwarves, said to have been freed from illithid captivity by a strange and capricious god, and widely rumoured to be afflicted with insanity and strange visions.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Undercommon, Shanatan\n§Y*§! Can gain the Berserker trait.
The desert giants live mainly as nomads in the wilds of Zakhara. But their own legends tell of a time when they built great cities, which were taken from them by the jann.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Midani
The deva variety of aasimar are not exactly mortals with celestial ancestry, but rather angelic souls trapped in a cycle of reincarnation into mortal bodies.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Celestial
The Diaman are a grey-skinned people from the westernmost edges of Malatra, settled near the southernmost ruins of Anok-Imaskar.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Lidahan
The Djinni are genies of Elemental Air, benevolent, haughty and ultimately mercurial like the winds.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Jannti, Auran
A dracolich is an undead dragon, animated by a specialised ritual devised by Sammaster, the fallen chosen of Mystra, and disseminated by the Cult of the Dragon.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Draconic
Dragons are among the most ancient intelligent creatures of Faerûn, and the most diverse. All are huge winged lizards, but they vary greatly in habitat, abilities, and temperament.
Draegloths are four-armed drow-demon hybrids, usually conceived as part of the rituals of Lolth the Spider Queen.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Drowic
The Draeven people live around the shores of the Dragonmere at the western end of the Sea of Fallen Stars, and in the Western Heartlands beyond.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Thorasta

Dragons are among the most ancient intelligent creatures of Faerûn, and the most diverse. All are huge winged lizards, but they vary greatly in habitat, abilities, and temperament.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Draconic

The Dragonborn of Bahamut were created by the Platinum Dragon as holy warriors for his faith and war against Tiamat. They were all created from his faithful in a ritual, shaped in the image of dragonborn of Abeir.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Draconic

Dragonborn, and their close kind the dragonspawn, are humanoids drawn from the same ancient ancestral stock that gave rise to the true dragons. Many of them were enslaved to the dragon overlords of Abeir for countless generations.

Dragonspawn, or Spawn of Tiamat, are the goddess' answer to Bahamut's dragonborn. They are created from dragon eggs, and can take on a variety of forms to enact the will of their cruel deity.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Draconic

The most widespread drow group, the Udadrow are also the most notorious owing to their leaders' frequent devotion to the Abyssal powers, especially Lolth. But many of them shun this fanaticism and seek other paths.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Drowic

The D'tarig are a hardy community of herders and traders most often encountered in the desert of Anauroch. They are short of stature, and some believe them to be descended from Low Netherese humans and the dwarves of Tethyamar.\n§ZCourt Language§!: D'tarig

Descended from a dwarven clan in old Shanatar who were enslaved by illithids, the duergar or gray dwarves are seen as dour, serious, and possessed of an unremittingly bleak and pitiless outlook.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Duergan\n§Y*§! Can gain the Berserker trait.

The Durpari people come from the surrounding lands on the Golden Water in the far southeast of Faerûn. They value freedom and commerce above all else, and are known for their tolerance of any and all races.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Durpari

The Duskers hail from the Dusk Ports in the southwest of Laerakond, originally on Abeir. The Dusk Ports are thriving mercantile cities, but for many years they have existed in the shadow of Laerakond's mighty dragon overlords.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Thorass

Dwarves, also known as the Deep Folk, are stocky humanoids commonly associated with underground habitats and fine handicrafts. They have lived on Toril and Abeir since time immemorial, and their cultures span both worlds.
Created by the Primordials of Abeir as some of their foremost servants, Earth Titans are enourmous beings, as patient and unbreakable as the rock they resemble.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Primordial

The primordial powers of earth emerge in the hidden depths of the Elemental Plane of Earth, and to them, the Material Plane is a flimsy thing of little consequence.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Primordial, Terran

The dwarves of Earthfast are an offshoot of the Shield Dwarves found elsewhere in Faerûn. Their culture is somewhat influenced by the humans of the Vast, although they largely keep to themselves.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Galenan\n§Y*§! Can gain the Berserker trait.

The dwarves of the Earthroot and surrounding areas are an offshoot of the Shield Dwarves found further west in Faerûn. They trade with the humans of the lands above, and are noted for their steadfastness.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Galenan\n§Y*§! Can gain the Berserker trait.
Earth genasi, sometimes called earthsouls, are people with ancestral ties to the Elemental Plane of Earth, and its residents such as dao.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Terran

The human-majority culture of the Vast is a mix of Damaran and Chondathan traditions. This hybrid culture is marked by the distinctive dialect spoken in the area, which is known as Easting.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Easting
The Efreeti are genies of Elemental Fire. They often saw themselves as superior beings and the natural masters of all other creatures.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Jannti, Ignan

The einheriar are immortal planar beings from upper planes such as Arcadia. Those encountered on the Material Plane are usually members of organised warbands serving the divine powers.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Celestial

The fey eladrin, or noble eladrin, are elves whose ties to Faerie lend their bodies the power to shift with their emotions, reflecting the moods of the world's seasons.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Elvish, Sylvan

The fey elves, sometimes called eladrin after their distant celestial relations, are elves who have maintained their ancestral connections to the mysterious otherworld known as the Feywild, or Faerie.
Emerald dragons commonly live in warm climates. They are said to be fascinated by history and humanoid customs, but paranoid and unwilling to share their discoveries.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Draconic

Empyreans are the offspring of deities and other powerful immortals. They partake of the same immortal nature themselves, and find mortality hard to understand.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Celestial, Infernal, Abyssal
Equinals are horse-like guardinals, celestials from the Blessed Fields of Elysium.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Celestial

The Eraka are a collection of horse-riding tribes native to the Ride region, north of the Dragonspine Mountains. They are seen as fiercely independent, and are related to both the Ulutiun peoples of the Great Glacier and to the Rengarth barbarians of ancient Low Netheril.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Erakic
Erinyes are a variant of Baatezu that can be in passing be confused for celestial beings. They often act as special agents to the Lords of the Hells.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Infernal

The Eshowe are a rare subgroup of the Chultan people who were led from Katashaka to Chult by the coatls. After settling in Chult, the Eshowe were betrayed and slaughtered by their own tutelary god, Eshowdow. Few now remain compared to their height.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Eshowan

The Eskornar are the inhabitants of the Wild Dragon Realm of Eskorn, a barely-held together monarchy of the descendants of the rebellious slaves of the dragon Eskornamundyr.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Thorass\n§Y*§! Access to the Tanistry succession.

The Numtanajd people of the highlands of Zakhara are habitual pastoralists, keeping sheep in mountain foothills alongside the nomadic Badia. They have many distinctive traditions, governing everything from getting out of bed to marriage and veiling.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Midani

The Fankiang are a nomadic people of the eastern Endless Waste. Many of them are sworn to an ancestral feud with the Commani.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Chuchian\n§Y*§! Access to the Ultimogeniture succession.
The fey are a diverse collection of beings native to the mystical otherworld known as the Feywild. On Toril, they often dwell in forests and other wild places.

The Fey'ri, also known as Daemonfey, are the descendants of ancient sun elves and demons from the abyss, created during the Crown Wars as an attempt to strengthen the ruling lines of Cormanthor and Siluvanede.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Elvish, Abyssal

The Ffolk are the main human cultural group of the Moonshae Isles. They are descended from the ancient Talfir of the Chionthar Valley region in Faerûn. The Ffolk value self-reliance, individual responsibility and loyalty to their families and communities.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Waelan\n§Y*§! Access to the Tanistry succession.

Fiends are immortal outsiders from the Lower Outer Planes. The two largest groups of fiends, the baatezu and the tanar'ri, are locked in an aeons-old conflict known as the Blood War, in which other groups such as yugoloths intervene for their own benefit.

The reclusive firbolg are one of the giantkin races, resembling great humans. Theirs is an isolationist culture, and are all seen as inherently sinful creatures by other giants and giantkin.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Firbolg, Jotun\n§Y*§! Access to the Tanistry succession.

Fire giants, or Ildjotunen, live in hot regions, especially around volcanoes. They are known as expert crafters, but they also have a reputation for cruelty and slavery.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Jotunild, Jotun
The primordial powers of fire are born in the heart of the Elemental Plane of Fire, and generally see the Material Plane as little more than fuel and tinder.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Primordial
Fire genasi, sometimes called flamesouls, are people with ancestral ties to the Elemental Plane of Fire, and its residents such as the Efreet.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Ignan

Firenewts, also known as salamen, are a variety of lizardfolk who are specialised to live in volcanic regions. They have a reputation for cruelty and treachery, and many of them worship the elemental powers Kossuth and Imix.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Draconic, Ignan\n§Y*§! Can gain the Berserker trait.
The seas and lakes of Toril are home to many sentient fish-like species, some of whom become involved in the business of land-dwellers.
Flinds are a variety of gnoll, bigger, stronger and more vicious. They often subjugate their smaller kin and take leadership positions in their packs and warbands.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Gnoll

A subgroup of the Cloud Giants, the Fog Giants, or Skodjotunen, eschew the fancier lifestyles of their more well-known kin in favour of a nomadic life of hunting and stealth.\n§ZCourt Language§!:Jotunskye, Jotun

Fomorians are a variety of giant who were once forest-dwellers like their cousins the Voadkyn, but were cursed and driven underground after the god Karontor led them in an attempted conquest of the Feywild.
§ZCourt Language§!: Jotun
§Y*§! Access to the Tanistry succession.
§Y*§! Can gain the Berserker trait.
§Y*§! Cannot take arcane classes.

Forest gnomes are a rare and habitually reclusive gnomish sub-culture who prefer to live in isolation in remote woodlands. They generally have little connection to outsiders, even other gnomes, unless driven to travel by external pressures.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Gnim

Frost giants, or Isejotunen, dwell on high mountains and glaciers, and in parts of the polar regions of Toril. They are renowned as warriors, but have a reputation for ignorance and poor social skills.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Jotunise, Jotun\n§Y*§! Can gain the Berserker trait.

Gehreleths, also known as demodands, are fiends from the Tarterian Depths of Carceri. On their home plane they serve as jailers to a range of supernatural captives, and when they are summoned to the Material Plane, it is often to serve as guards of some kind.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Demodand

Gelugons, otherwise known as ice devils, are a variety of baatezu native to the coldest parts of Baator, such as Cania and Stygia. They serve as senior commanders in the Blood War, answering directly to the pit fiends.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Infernal

Gem dragons are noted for their glittering scales, their psychic prowess, and their general philosophical indifference to good and evil. Many of them are reclusive, but some choose to live close beside other species in order to study them.
Genasi are human-like creatures whose ancestry includes creatures native to the elemental planes, especially genies.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Primordial

Genies are powerful elemental beings, most of whom are native to the elemental Inner Planes. Their highest nobles are famed for the ability to grant wishes, and they have intervened in Toril's history many times in the past.

Ghaunadans are amorphous slime creatures created by the ancient deity Ghaunadaur. They are capable of shaping themselves into humanoid appearances to interact with outsiders, but they prefer to emulate their formless creator.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Abyssal

The Ghostwise halflings split from their kinfolk in ancient Luiren when they adopted the worship of the fierce god Malar. Although most of them have long since recanted this practice, they still lead largely separate lives. They have distinctive cultural practices, including knowledge of barbarian warrior paths and esoteric psychic disciplines.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Luiric

The Jotunbrud, sometimes known as the True Giants, are gigantic humanoids who claim descent from their supreme deity, Annam All-Father. Most of them hold to the sacred traditions of the Ordning, which impart a distinctive set of moral values to giantkind.

The gith are a human-like species who take their name from the ancient liberator Gith, who freed them from ages-long enslavement by the mind flayers. Not native to Toril, they dwell mostly in distant cosmic realms, and only come to the surface world to pursue their ancestral vendettas.

Githvyrik is the name given to those who refused to take a side in the great schism between Gith and Zerthimon after the fall of the mind flayer empire. Many githvyrik live as pirates in Wildspace, while a few, including the most ancient members of the culture, are solitary psychic warriors with private esoteric philosophies.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Gith

Githyanki is the name given to those who remained loyal to Gith the Liberator when Zerthimon rebelled against her. Gith and her successor Vlaakith the First led the githyanki to dwell in the timeless void of the Astral Plane, where they are visited by their sworn allies, the red dragons.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Gith

Githzerai is the name given to those who sided with Zerthimon when he challenged Gith's leadership of her liberated people. Zerthimon and his heir, Zaerith Menyar-ag-Gith, led the githzerai to the swirling plane of Limbo, where they became anarchs, masters of chaos-shaping.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Gith
Glabrezu are demons who specialise in corrupting mortals through promises of power. They live to spread corruption, and can be powerful combatants when cornered.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Abyssal

Gnolls are hyenalike humanoids who roam open plains across Toril. In ancient times many of them worshipped a god called Gorellik. But with the passage of time, the demon lord Yeenoghu became the principal deity of the gnolls, and it is even rumoured that he can create new, more faithful gnolls by magically converting wild hyenas.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Gnoll\n§Y*§! Can gain the Berserker trait.

Rock gnomes are the commonest gnomish culture, and can be found throughout much of Faerûn and Zakhara. They live mainly in small towns, and are noted for their ingenuity and sense of fun.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Gnim

Gnomes are diminutive humanoids, smaller than most other humanoids except halflings. They are sometimes called the Forgotten Folk, but they are found alongside humans throughout the material world and the Feywild.

Goblins are the physically smallest of the group of cultures and species to which they give their name, but also by far the most numerous. Goblins can be found in practically every climate, either in villages of their own, or alongside their larger kin, or orc and humans. Exiled from their ancestral home in the Feywild, they are seen as both foolish and cunning - a paradox which reflects their great diversity and adaptability.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Ghukliak

There are many kinds of goblinoid, some of which are too rare to form independent cultures. They are distinguished by their hardiness, their ability to adapt to many climates, and their ancient roots in the Feywild.

Among the most powerful of dragons, gold dragons are renowned for their wisdom and insight. They can dwell in almost any environment, and some a rumoured to walk among other species in magical disguises.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Draconic

Gold dwarves, also known as Hill Dwarves, are a widespread dwarven culture whose traditional homeland is the Great Rift, a vast canyon and cavern complex at the heart of the plains of the Shaar. They traditionally put great store in material wealth and family honour, but the pressures of life in the Rift lead many to strike out on other paths.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Riftspeak\n§Y*§! Can gain the Berserker trait.
Golems are synthetic life-forms animated by magic, either arcane or divine.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Thorass

Gol-Kaa, sometimes called Goliaths by outsiders, are among the smallest of the giants. Commonly associated with the cultures of their larger cousins, they also form communities of their own in remote or mountainous regions.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Gol-Kaa, Shanatan, Jotun

The Gontese are a mixed human and dragonborn culture of Laerakond descended from the pioneers who settled around the Glaur Barrens in the wake of the Blue Breath of Change.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Draconic

The Gormeel are an offshoot of the Slaad race that are living proof that Chaos can randomly create Order. They are sworn enemies of their more common kin, and often are found living with Githzerai.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Slaadi, Gith

Gray orcs were brought from another world millennia ago by the theurgist Thayd. After their defeat in the Orcgate Wars, they scattered across much of northern and eastern Faerûn, often forming small nomadic communities.\n§Y*§! Can gain the Berserker trait.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Daraktan

Also called fang dragons, gray dragons are most often found in mountains and rocky wildernesses. They are aggressive and callous, and some say that they were created from other dragons by an evil deity trespassing on Tiamat's domain.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Draconic

Green dragons, also known as forest dragons, usually dwell in woodlands, although some compete with black dragons for territory in swamps. They are known as conniving manipulators, fond of elaborate personal schemes.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Draconic

Green elves, also known as wild elves or grugach, live mostly apart from the rest of elven civilisation. Compared to their close kin the wood elves, they live a more nomadic lifestyle, and to favour empheral artforms such as music over visual arts and architecture.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Green Elvish
The Gugari people, predominantly spirit-folk, were among the earliest settlers to come to the Katakoro Plateau, and they established the first permanent cities there.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Sylvan
The guardinals are a collection of animal-like celestials from the Blessed Fields of Elysium. They come to the Material Plane only rarely.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Celestial
The gugari are a secluded group of spirit folk descended from the kingdom of Guge. They possess a strict social hierarchy, where social mobility was unheard of.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Shou
The Gur people are nomads originating in the northern Hordelands. They generally maintain good relations with the Oigur and Tuigan peoples.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Gur

Gurri is the name given to the scattered population of Gurs in western Faerûn. They are descended from nomads who fled westward during the ancient war between Raumathar and Narfell. Small groups of them now live an itinerant life on the trade routes of Faerûn, or in small communities in larger cities.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Gurri

The Guychiang are a semi-nomadic people from the Plain of Horses. They live at the foot of the Chigidi mountains, and are renowned among the tribes for their agricultural prowess.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Chuchian\n§Y*§! Access to the Ultimogeniture succession.

The Hadhar people are a strongly urbanised multi-species culture from central Zakhara. With the spread of the Qisma'ite faiths, they rose to dominance over many older cultures from the wider region.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Midani

Hags are ageless fey that represent the more brutal, malevolent and subversive side of nature. They are spiteful creatures, universally ugly and often manifest in many different subtypes.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Hag, Rashemi, Jotun
Hagspawn are the unfortunate sons of hags, blessed with their strength and endurance and cursed with their foul looks.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Rashemi

The Hai are the native people of the province of Hai Yuan, formerly known as Karatin. They are considered the most self-assured and confident of all Shou peoples, renowned as sea traders and pirates. \n§ZCourt Language§!: Shou
Half-elves whose recent elven ancestry stems from the Feywild are sometimes called half-eladrin. \n§ZCourt Language§!: Elvish, Sylvan, Thorasta

Half-giants can have many kinds of giant ancestry. They have few distinct settlements of their own in modern times, but are credited with the foundation of the Second Kingdom of Nog in Zakhara and the realm of Hartsvale in northern Faerûn. \n§ZCourt Language§!: Jotun, Illuskan

Half-gnolls were once common when gnolls worshipped Gorellik, but have become rarer with the rise of the bestial rites of Yeenoghu. They often look like fur-covered humans with hyena-like teeth.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Gnoll

Green Elves do not often associate with humans, but occasional mixed-race children are born who usually associate with the culture of one or the other of their parents.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Green Elvish, Thorasta

The Moon Elves have lived alongside humans for many centuries, and their offspring are among the commonest kinds of half-elf. They are frequently assimilated into urban human societies, and rarely form settlements of their own.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Elvish, Thorasta
Half-ogres are the offspring of humans and ogres and rarely form communities of their own, but are prized as mercenaries for their strength and resilience.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Thorasta, Jogishk

Half-orcs are found in significant numbers wherever orcs and humans live nearby one another. They rarely form separate societies, but often live alongside their orcish or human kin.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Thorasta, Daraktan
It is rare for sea-elves to associate closely with humans, but half-sea-elves can also be born of liaisons with merfolk, which are somewhat more common. \n§ZCourt Language§!: Sea Elvish, Thorasta

The Shadar-Kai travel extensively in the Shadowfell, and mingle with many cultures there. Half-Shadar-Kai can be found in Gloomwrought, Evernight, and other major settlements of the Shadowfell.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Elvish, Thorasta

The Sun Elves often hold themselves aloof from humans, but they still associate with them enough for half-Sun Elves to be quite widespread. They usually live alongside their human kin to avoid Sun Elf prejudice.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Elvish, Thorasta

Wood Elves often form passing liaisons with solitary humans who live or work in their domains. Their offspring have a reputation as good rangers, and are associated with the goddess Mielikki in her aspect as the half-elf Khalreshaar. \n§ZCourt Language§!: Elvish, Thorasta
Malisons are a kind of yuan-ti whose bodies express some features of the humanoid purebloods and some features of the serpentine abominations. \n§ZCourt Language§!: Yuan-ti

Halflings are a diminutive group of humanoids found on many worlds, whose origins on Toril seem to be in the southern lands of Luiren. They are found in many other places, often living alongside humans. \n§ZCourt Language§!: Luiric

The halflings of Toril, and of the alien world of Mystara, refer to themselves collectively as Hin. Although their cultures are diverse, they are generally more peaceable than humans, and given to rural and agricultural pursuits.

The Halruaan people are descended from the indigenous Lapal folk of the eastern Shining Sea, and Netherese refugees who fled the fall of High Netheril. They are found in Halruaa and Nimbral, and have a reputation a skilled magic-users.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Halruaan

Hamadryads are rare woodland spirits, closely affiliated to treants, and each bound to a mighty tree. They are elusive but powerful, and many of them have developed great magical talents.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Dryadic, Elvish

Beholders are many-eyed aberrations that each think of themselves as the perfect lifeform and ideal child of the Great Mother. H'Cathan beholders are offworlders, who live in the disc-like world of H'Catha, at the far edge of Realmspace.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Quevquel

The Heldann people are outworlders from Mystara, who were organized in independent states called Freeholds until they were overrun by the militaristic order of the Heldannic Knights. The Knights wield powerful magic and commanded flying ships called warbirds.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Heldannic

Hengeyokai are natural shapechangers, found throughout Kara-Tur, and more rarely in the Hordelands and Faerûn. Each one has a specific animal affinity which governs the forms they can change between. \n§ZCourt Language§!: Kozakuran

The high elves are a collection of elven cultures whose forebears came from Faerie, or the Feywild, in ancient times to establish mighty empire on Toril. Some view themselves as close to their fey elf kin who still partially reside in Faerie, while others think of themselves as wholly distinct.

The people living along the Sword Coast are a complex mixture of Illuskan, Tethyrian, ancient Talfir, and many travellers from further afield. This hybrid culture has no single fixed name, but is as commonly called High Coaster as anything else. \n§ZCourt Language§!: Thorasta

Hill giants are considered the lowest of the true giants, according to the teachings of the Ordning. Famed for their appetites, they live mainly in rough, hilly terrain, disdained by their larger cousins. \n§ZCourt Language§!: Jotunhaug, Jotun§Y\n*§! Can gain the Berserker trait.

Hobgoblins, like their smallers cousins the goblins, dwelled long ago in the Feywild, but most of them were exiled to the Material Plane by the tyrrany of the goblin deity Maglubiyet. They form a more regimented culture than other goblinkin, and are also renowned as animal breeders. \n§ZCourt Language§!: Ghukliak, Hobgoblin

The Hungtse people live mainly in the Shou province of the same name, around the fertile valleys of the Hungtse and Chan Lu. Their lands produce much of Kara-Tur's rice, tea, and silk, while the people themselves are seen as talkative and hot-tempered. They are also famed for the quality and diversity of their food. \n§ZCourt Language§!: Shou

The Uluik people, or Ice Hunters, are ulutiuans that migrated out of the Great Glacier, westwards onto the lands of the Icewind Dale. They are a private people, often having secondary names that they give to outsiders instead of their birth names.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Uluik

The Igidujin are a people from where the Taan meets the Ama Basin. They are more settled than the other people of the Endless Wastes, and are known as fierce raiders.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Chuchian\n§Y*§! Access to the Ultimogeniture succession.

Mainstream Illithid culture is strongly dominated by the worship of the deity Ilsensine, and adherence to a family of related philosophical creeds by which the mind flayers justify and ground their existence in the material world. \n§ZCourt Language§!: Qualith

The illithids, or mind flayers, are a species of hybrid beings created by implanting small Far Realm beings known as tadpoles into humanoid hosts. Their culture is highly preoccupied by mental matters and psionics, and they usually regard other species as closer to livestock than peers.

The Illuskan people trace their cultural heritage to seafarers from Ruathym during the era of ancient Netheril. They are named for the great city of Illusk, on whose ruins the later city of Luskan was founded. They are famed as travellers and navigators, as well as mercenaries. 
§ZCourt Language§!: Illuskan
§Y*§! Can commission runestones.
§Y*§! Can gain the Berserker trait.
§Y*§! Court Skald minor title.

The human-dominated Illuskan cultures are found throughout the North. While many trace their origins to seafarers of the Trackless Sea in times past, they are mixed to a significant extent with the survivors of Low Netheril.

The Imaskari people were the dominant culture of the ancient empire of Imaskar, and its eastern successor, Anok-Imaskar. These lands were renowned for their magical prowess, but since their fall, the true Imaskari people have largely vanished, reduced to a rumour, or an historical note.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Roushoum

The Imaskari cultures once spread from the Great Sea to the Hordelands, and from Mulhorand to Chukei. The fall of Imaskar to a slave rebellion left a wide range of successor states and cultures, some of which endure to the present day.

The Impilturan people are largely descended from the survivors of the fall of Jhaamdath, along with the Damaran people from the highlands surrounding Impiltur. They are famed for their resistance against encroaching demonic armies and their followers.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Damaran
The Inevitables are automata from the Clockwork Plane of Mechanus, tasked with enforcing the cosmic laws of death, time, and divinity.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Celestial, Infernal, Abyssal

Island giants are enormous, long-lived giants from the islands around Zakhara. They have some physical resemblances to oni and cyclopes, but do not seem to be closely related to them.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Midani
The Issacortae people live in the Ama Basin in northern Kara-Tur. They are semi-nomadic, and are noted for being one of the more organised of the Amaese.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Issacortae

The Iulutiun are the most numerous and widespread of all the Ulutiuan peoples. They are tough and adaptable, and of the Ulutiuans, they are the most welcoming of outsiders.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Ulutiun\n§Y*§! Access to the Eldership succession.

Jann are genies who are native to the Material Plane. Unlike other genies, they blend all four elements in their bodies and in their magic. They often live as nomads in wild and desert places.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Midani, Jannti

Jaziran, or Islander, is a broad cultural category which encompasses most of the human peoples of the islands of the Crowded Sea, except for the Affa in the east and the Akotans in the west. They are often seafarers, and frequently cultivate symbiotic relationships with the creatures of the seas and islands.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Midani

The Jungle Giants are said to have been the ancient founders of the First Kingdom of Nog. In more recent times, they live in smaller tribal groups in the forests of eastern Zakhara.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Noga

The Kadari culture flourished during the heyday of the kingdom of Kadar, before the time of the First Caliph. Little is known of its origins, but the rivalry between Kadar and the Six Dynasties of the Second Kingdom of Nog is remembered to this day.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Kadari

The Kashghun are a mostly nomadic culture of the Plain of Horses, in and around the Quoya desert. Unlike the more western nomads, they are known for having a few great cities that they retreat to in the winter.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Chuchian\n§Y*§! Access to the Ultimogeniture succession.

The Kao people dwell primarily in the mountain province of Kao Shan in Shou Lung. They are known as hardy mountain folk with little time for the ways of lowlanders. They are famed as archers, and are reputed to eat the meat of carnivorous animals such as bears.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Shou
The peoples of the Katakoro Plateau are a hybrid mix of Shou and old Imaskari ancestry, and their culture has also been influenced by commerce with the lands of the Golden Water.

The Katanga are shapeshifters who each prefer a specific animal form alongside a more humanoid one. They live primarily on the Malatran Plateau, and are believed to be distant kin to the Hengeyokai from the lands of the Celestial Sea.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Malatran

There are many cultures across Katashaka, a large and varied continent. Best known to the wider Realms, and especially to the people of Akota, Chult, and Nimbral, is the region around the port city of Taerloon, and it is to the people of this region that they give the name Katashakan.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Katashakan

Katashaka is a continent lying far to the southwest of Faerûn. Humans from Katashaka migrated to other lands millennia ago, following the defeat of the colossal god-beast, or nyama-nummo, named the Sleeper.

The Kenku are the Faerûnian cousins of the bird-folk known as Tengu, who are most commonly found in Wa and Kozakura. The Kenku are found throughout Faerûn and its Underdark, but rarely form large settlements. Outside Veldorn, they are commonest along the Sword Coast North.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Auran, Kenku
The Khassidi are the northwesternmost of the Taan peoples, living off the land in large part to their horses.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Khassidi\n§Y*§! Access to the Ultimogeniture succession.

The Khatin people are a mainly human group from the mountains fringing the Katakoro Plateau. They came to be the dominant culture of the plateau some time after the fall of the ancient Gugari and Maviddi kingdoms.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Ra-Khatian, Khazari

Khayal are genies who primarily dwell on the Shadowfell, where their dismal capital is the City of Onyx. To those who know of them at all, they are noted for their skills in deception.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Thorass, Jannti
Khorvairan is a catch-all term for the many outworlder peoples that live in the bustling continent of Khorvaire, in the far-off and isolated world of Eberron.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Galifaran

Kobolds a a diminutive species of draconic bipeds. They are known for their skill in sorcery and trap-making. Some kobold philosophers say that the use of personal combat to settle differences keeps most kobold communities from going to war with each other.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Yipyak

The Korpokkur are dwarves, originally native to the islands of Wa and Kozakura, where they are called Korobokuru by humans. Nowadays they are found in wild places throughout much of Kara-Tur, especially around the Ama Basin. Often seen by outsiders as uncouth, they have an intricate system of tribal governance and justice. 
§ZCourt Language§!: Korpokkur, Shou
§Y*§! Access to the Eldership succession.
§Y*§! Can gain the Berserker trait.

The Koryoan people are native to the Koryo peninsula in north-eastern Kara-Tur. They are famed for their defensive military traditions, which have several times protected their kingdoms from invasion by Kozakura.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Koryoan

The Kozakuran people are the principal inhabitants of the island of Shinkoku and the surrounding archipelago. They are closely related to the Wanese people, whom they often regard as their rivals. Kozakuran society is firmly stratified into castes, governed by the samurai.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Kozakuran

The piscine kuo-toa are amphibious, despite their appearance. They are often mentally unstable, which frequently translates to a religious fanaticism that dominates their society.\n§ZCourt Language§!:Kuo-toan

The Kuong people are indigenous to the theocratic Kuong Kingdom, in the easternmost region of Malatra. They are related to the neighbouring Purang tribes, but their language shows no known relationship to any other.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Kuong

Lamias are centaur-like creatures who usually live in remote deserts. The commoners are similar to wemics, having the lower bodies of lions, but their nobles have the lower bodies of huge serpents instead. Lamias often eat human flesh, and are accordingly regarded as a menace by many of their neighbours.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Abyssal

The Lantanna culture is a mixture of human and gnomish traditions, and originates on the island of Lantan in the Trackless Sea. The Lantanna are famed for their artificers, and many technological innovations have eventually reached Faerûn after being developed on Lantan first.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Lantanna

The Lapal, or sometimes Lapalians, are a near-extinct human group from the Chultan Peninsula and the Shaar. They were hunted down and enslaved by the Yuan-ti, and most of their descendants now consider themselves either Tashalan or Halruaan. A few Lapal live on in isolated communities, still clinging to their old traditions.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Lapal, Yuan-ti, Tashalan

The Lapal peoples are descended from former slaves of the yuan-ti in the Mhair Jungles and the surrounding area, who won their freedom in ages past after the arrival of the Chultans from Katashaka. Some remained in the area where they had lived previously, while others spread out north and east into the lands beyond.

The LeShay are a group of pale-skinned elfkin who have long resided in seclusion in the Feywild. They are viewed as alien even by the eladrin who share their otherworldly home.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Elvish, Sylvan

The Lighfoot halflings are the most widespread of their kind, thanks in large part to their wanderlust. They tend to be minorities in nearly all lands they inhabit, save for the halfling home country of Luiren.\n§ZCourt Language§!:Luiric, Thorasta

Known among themselves as the Kecualas, the Lizardfolk of Faerûn are a varied lot, sometimes friendly to the soft-skinned races and sometimes hostile. In either case, theirs is a traditionalist and often patriarchal culture, especially when not being subjugated by other scaled races.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Lizardfolk, Draconic\n§Y*§! Can gain the Berserker trait.

The Llewyrr are an isolationist offshoot of Sun Elves that live in the Moonshae Isles. They are often only found in their city of Synnoria, and are strict vegetarians. They tend to be hositle to all non-fey outsiders, especially humans and other elves.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Elvish\n§Y*§! Access to the Tanistry succession.

The Lorendrow, or Greenshadow Elves, are a small drow group which fled from the cataclysm that drove their cousins underground, moving instead to southern jungles where they largely live in seclusion.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Drowic
Elves with a natural form of lycanthrophy, the Lythari are a rare type of elf only found in the farthest reaches of the Endless Wastes and in Evermeet.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Elvish
The peoples of the isolated southern valleys of the Shao Mountains are known as the Mahasiswa. There they have constructed a thriving civilization.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Lidahan

The Mai are one of the Shou people, hailing from the northern province of Mai Yuan. They are considered closer to the horse riders of the Taan than the rest of the Shou peoples, and in ancient times had their own realm.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Shou\n§Y*§! Access to the Ultimogeniture succession.

A mutant offshoot of Sahuagin, the Malenti look not like their fish-like progenitors, but are instead near-identical to Sea Elves. They are treated as third class citizens at best by the Sahuagin, and often used as spies and saboteurs in their wars against the Sea Elves.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Sahuagin

Maraloi are an oft-forgotten race of elf found extremely rarely in Kara-Tur. One of the unique characteristics of the Maraloi was their weakness to iron, with the metal acting as if poison to the touch.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Maraloi
The Mar are the native people of the Utter East, long ago subjugated by a mixed fleet of Northlanders and Ffolk who arrived at their shores due to a magical mishap.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Maran

Genies of elemental water, the Marids are proud and mercurial. Individually the most powerful of genie-kind, the Marids consider all to be inferior beings, and only grudgingly accept interactions with genies and humans, while all other beigns receiving only scorn.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Aquan, Jannti
Mariliths are the militant generals of the Tanar'ri race, capable of cold, calculating logic where other demons are driven by passion alone.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Abyssal

The Marrash are fiends with the body of humans, wings and feet of birds and heads of jackals. They are evil spirits of plague, and have a long-lasting partnership with the Yikaria.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Infernal, Yikaria

The Maviddi are a half-elven people of unknown ancestry, found in the forests of the Katakoro Plateau. They once had a kingdom that covered the area, until it was destroyed by Guge.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Ra-Khatian\n§Y*§! Access to the Ultimogeniture succession.
Mercury dragons are whimsical and impulsive metallic dragons who seem to live in a near-constant state of mania.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Draconic

Merrow are the longer-lived, aquatic variant of ogres. They have a particular fondness for tattoos, and are often more violent than land-bound ogres.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Jogishk\n§Y*§! Can gain the Berserker trait.

Descended from self-exiled Halruaan illusionists and their families, the Nimbrese are an isolationist people known best for their veneration of the goddess Leira and propensity for lies of all kinds.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Halruaan, Ruathlek
§Y*§! Can commission runestones.\n§Y*§! Can gain the Berserker trait.\n§Y*§! Court Skald minor title.
Obyriths are demons from the Abyss, more ancient and inscrutable even than the Tanar'ri. Among their number are some of the most feared Abyssal Lords.

The Oigur are a traditionally nomadic ethnic group of the southern Hordelands. They are traditionally allies of the more widely scattered Gurs.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Oigur\n§Y*§! Access to the Ultimogeniture succession.
Outsiders are creatures from beyond the Material Plane. Some belong to specific types, such as celestials or genies, but there are many more who do not fit such easy classification.
Outworlder is the name given to those whose origins lie on the Material Plane, but on worlds far from Toril itself.
The forests and wild places of Faerûn teem with hidden life, much of it more intelligent than others realise. Some of the plants are sentient beings with cultures of their own.
Qorrash are genies of cold and ice, who are distantly related to the Djinn. Each qorrashi is expected to serve dutifully, and although rare, they are prized as civil servants and advisers.

The Quirish are a nomadic people of the Hordelands with longstanding political and linguistic ties to the warlike Zamogedi and a rivalry with the Fankiang.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Quirish\n§Y*§! Access to the Ultimogeniture succession.

The Rakasta are catlike humanoids, similar to tabaxi. They are found on many worlds and across the planes. On Toril, they are most commonly found in the Vast and other lands to the northeast of the Sea of Fallen Stars.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Easting\n§Y*§! Access to the Eldership succession.
§Y*§! Access to the Wychlaran succession if higher than Duke tier.

The Raurindi people live primarily as nomads in Raurin and the Plains of Purple Dust. Some say they are descended from the Imaskari people whose empire once dominated the region, while others say they were once Zakharans who migrated north from Durpar.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Raurindi
§Y*§! Can commission runestones.\n§Y*§! Can gain the Berserker trait.\n§Y*§! Court Skald minor title.
The enigmatic Rilmani are outsiders from the Concordant Opposition of the Outlands. They are deeply preoccupied with ideas of cosmic balance, and rarely share their specific goals with mortals.

The Semphari people are a settled offshoot of the Raurindi. Their lands were long contested between Mulhorand and the nomads of Taan, but the Semphari people founded cities and prospered as traders between these nations in times of peace.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Semphari

The Seng people are a predominantly human group native to the Laothan highlands in eastern Malatra. They are seen as rustic and tribal by their neighbours in T'u Lung, but have historically maintained their independence.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Laothan
§Y*§! Access to the Open succession if nomadic tribal.
Shamblers, or shambling mounds, are animate plant creatures embodying underbrush and decaying vegetation. However, they can grow to great size and in some cases possess unexpected Intelligence.

Shield dwarves are one of the major branches of Toril's dwarves. They are found across the north and west of Faerûn, and are renowned for their fierceness and their artisanal skill.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Shanatan\n§Y*§! Can gain the Berserker trait.

One of the living incarnations of Chaos, the Slaad and their variants hail from the plane of Limbo where they embody its potential, unpredictability and, often, brutality. It is speculated by some sages that the Slaad are the heavily-altered planar descendants of the ancient Batrachi shapeshifters, though there is no definitive proof.

The Slaad are frog-like outsiders and living incarnations of Chaos itself. They have a convoluted caste system determined by age and colour, and react surprisingly well to bullying.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Slaad
The Ssurran are a spacefaring species of lizardfolk, found all across wildspace and in the planet Coliar..\n§ZCourt Language§!: Draconic

The Star Spawn are a highly diverse group of strange beings which serve unearthly powers, including those known as the Elder Evils. Although there are some common patterns among the Star Spawn, no two are the same.
Susurrus are intelligent plant creatures composed of mobile brush and thorn bushes. They are subtle and elusive, but can make their presence felt in combat when the occasion demands it.
The T'aghur are a nomadic people from the Plain of Horses in the Hordelands.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Chuchian\n§Y*§! Access to the Ultimogeniture succession.

The Talfir were a people that once spread across the Chionthar River valley, first arising when the elven kingdoms descended into constant wars. The Talfir had powerful bards that wielded magic from the Plane of Shadow. They eventually faded away when other human groups migrated into their territories, though their descendants live on as the Ffolk and Tethyrians.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Talfiric

The Tashalans were widely considered to be a beautiful people by other humans, with black hair and olive skin. They are one of the original human peoples of the Chultan Peninsula, having been long ago enslaved by the Sarrukh and only much later regaining their freedom.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Tashalan

The people of Tethyr are close-knit and value family and friends above most other things and tend to be quite hostile to the idea of slavery. They are looked down upon by the inhabitants of Calimshan, who once lorded over them during the time of the Shoon.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Chondathan
The Tethyrian peoples are descended from the mixing of several disparate peoples, but can trace their ancestry most strongly to the ancient Talfir tribes.
Treants are a variety of intelligent plant life with a strong physical resemblance to broadleaved trees. They live in dense forests, and can act as shepherds to regular trees.

The Tsu-Tsu are a semi-settled culture from the Plain of Horses. They originated as a rebel group of Fankiang, but are nowadays treated as their own distinct group.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Chuchian\n§Y*§! Access to the Ultimogeniture succession.

Urdunnirin are dwarves given special power over stone and metal by their god, Dumathoin, Keeper of Secrets Under the Mountain. They are rarely seen, even by other dwarves, but lived deep in the depths of the earth.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Shanatan\n§Y*§! Can gain the Berserker trait.

§Y*§! Access to the Eldership succession.
§Y*§! Can gain the Berserker trait.

§Y*§! Court Skald minor title.
Xixecals are the immortal offspring of deities representing cold, winter, anger and chaos. They are antisocial by nature, but even a very small group of them can effectively dominate a wide area.

The Zamogedi are a people of the northern Hordelands with a strong martial culture and marked disrespect for the settled peoples living on the margins of their territory.\n§ZCourt Language§!: Zamogedi\n§Y*§! Access to the Ultimogeniture succession.

The Triad is an alliance of Tyr, Ilmater and Torm, supported by a few other less-powerful deities. Together, they strive to oppose injustice and evil in the Realms and beyond.

The arcane magic of the Weave is a fact of life in the Realms, so it should come as no surprise that the deities who govern such matters are given high consideration, particularly in societies dominated by wizards and sorcerers.

§MOther Mechanics:§! Easier to intermarry with other faiths.

The Rashemi faith focuses on the worship of a group of deities known as the Three, known broadly in Faerûn as Chauntea, Mystra (later replaced by Selûne), and Mielikki, as well as a number of nature spirits. Their religion is also dominated by women, and favours arcane spellcasters over others.

The people of Chessenta worship a mixture of western and eastern deities, putting special emphasis on their draconic hero-founder Tchazzar. Their pantheon has mostly a Neutral outlook and focuses both on philosophy and militarism.

Focusing on the worship of [Root.WaukeenLoc] and Helm, as well as a host of lesser gods, this religion is particularly prevalent in the Lands of Intrigue and tends to concern itself with more mundane matters than Good or Evil.

The deities of knowledge and invention are headed by the god Oghma, who together with his allies seek to preserve and categorize the knowledge of the Realms. Their followers also share in this passion for learning and discovery, and highly value academic pursuits as a result.

§MDecisions:§! Retire to monastery.
§MOther Mechanics:§! Easier to intermarry with other faiths, Bonus tech point gain.

Sune Firehair leads a small pantheon of deities related to joy, beauty, and love. These gods encourage the pursuit of happiness and free love, while also condemning war, aggression, and the domination of others.

§MDecisions:§! Improve Appearance, Take Etiquette Lessons, Gender Alteration
§MAmbitions:§! Lose Shy
§MOther Mechanics:§! Better results when hiring smith for crown jewels, Cheaper Feasts, Cheaper Summer Fairs

The practices of the southern people of Calimshan share many similarities with neighbouring faiths, but also include a great many unique features as well. Though nearly every deity is acknowledged, a handful are held as being more important and given special consideration. Notably, the faithful accept and venerate powers held as evil by most outsiders.

§MDecisions:§! Petition [Root.IlmaterLoc] for Health, Retire to monastery
§MSettlement Decisions:§! Ward of [Root.IlmaterLoc]
§MOther Mechanics:§! Court Judge honorary title, Easier to intermarry with other faiths.

The people of the Lapal coast have similar practices to their Calishite relations, but with the notable difference of how each settlement has its own civic deity that is worshipped almost exclusively there. They also have a distinct distaste for reptilian gods due to their historic conflicts with the yuan-ti.

§MDecisions:§! Petition [Root.IlmaterLoc] for Health, Retire to monastery
§MSettlement Decisions:§! Ward of [Root.IlmaterLoc]
§MOther Mechanics:§! Ignores defensive attrition, Easier to intermarry with other faiths.

Chauntea is the Faerûnian goddess of life and bounty, who viewed herself as the embodiment of all things agrarian. The radical arm of the Church of Chauntea believes that as Chauntea personifies the whole earth, so her worship must be spread to all the ends of the world. Because of that, they are far more prone to proselytising than other patrons of Chauntea.

§RRival Deities§!: [Root.AurilLoc], [Root.MalarLoc], [Root.TalosLoc], Umberlee, Bane, Fzoul Chembryl, Iyachtu Xvim, Talona, Moander, [Root.BhaalLoc], [Root.MyrkulLoc], Kossuth, Bazim-Gorag

The Mulhorandi pantheon is headed by Horus-Re and encompasses a host of deities that were brought to Toril in distant times from a distant world, in response to the pleas of their followers who had been enslaved by the ancient Imaskari.

§MOther Mechanics:§! +15% moral authority, loses piety in wars against the faithful, penalty to spymaster's "Steal Technology" action, Hard to convert.

The Untheric pantheon was brought to Toril long ago from another realm, in an attempt to free their followers from enslavement by the Imaskari. Though headed by Gilgeam, many deific wars have extracted a toll on the pantheon and most of its members are dead.

§MDecisions:§! Meliorism.

The halfling pantheon is led by Yondalla the Protector and Provider, and encompasses a number of gods held to be her children. The pantheon itself reflects the halfling people, being cohesive and good-natured.

§MDecisions:§! Study another faith
§MOther Mechanics:§! Defensive unit modifiers, Ignores defensive attrition.

The Solar faith worships either Lathander or [Root.AmaunatorLoc], varying by worshipper and time period, as the highest god and embodiment of the sun, as well as a small number of related deities.

§MDecisions:§! Employ Siamorphan Steward, Meliorism
§MOther Mechanics:§! Greater chance of converting, No short reign penalty, Attacking the same religion causes piety loss.

The deities of fury are a group of gods dominated by Talos, who each embody the destructive side of nature. They tend to be ruthless and vindictive, and use their infamy to instill fear and submission in rival faiths.

The gods of nature are led by Silvanus and encompass those deities who rule over natural forces, with care taken to placate the more destructive powers. They urge their followers to protect natural places and to attempt to attain balance between it and settled peoples.

§MOther Mechanics:§! Easier intermarriage, ignores defensive attrition, +5% morale, Rite of passage to adulthood.

Kossuth is the primordial of elemental fire whose portfolio is both the destructive and purifying power of flames. His church is hierarchical and impersonal, and mostly does without the guidance from their distant deity. They are opposed in all matters to the servants of elemental water.

§RRival Religions§!: Chauntean, Myriadic, Qisma'ite, Pantheist, Kahin, Infernal, Abyssal, Entropist, Faithless, Asathalfinare

§MSpecial CBs:§! County Conquest
§MOther Mechanics:§! Attacking same religion loses piety.

Grumbar, the primordial of earth, has his own organized faith originating in Zakhara, whose priesthood claimed to be able to interpret Fate through their elemental magics. Geomancers are also unique amongst the elemental cults in that they strive to combine both arcane and divine magic in their workings.

§RRival Deities§!: [Root.AkadiLoc], Urdlen, Elemental Evil
§RRival Religions§!: Infernal, Abyssal, Faithless, Entropist, Myriadic, Qisma'ite, Panthesit, Kahin

The elemental primordials, though usually far more distant than the gods who dominate the Realms, still possess a fair number of followers. Their cults and churches tend to be scattered and heterodox, varying significantly from region to region.

§MDecisions:§! Summon Genie
§MSpecial CBs:§! Coastal Conquest

The people of the Endless Wastes follow a small group of nature gods and practice ancestor worship, as well as some beast cults. They do not have any gods they consider to be evil, instead blaming it on malefic spirits.

Uthgar, the Battle Father is the patron demigod of the Uthgardt people. As a mortal, Uthgar was a great barbarian thane who famously slew and was slain in turn by Gurt, the Lord of the Pale Giants. In recognition of his martial prowess, [Root.TempusLoc], Lord of Battles elevated Uthgar to godhood and his followers became his first worshippers, calling themselves the Uthgardt after him.

The gods of warfare are led by [Root.TempusLoc]. He and his fellow gods exhort their followers to be brave and to join conflicts they find. They do not, however, condone senseless slaughter of noncombatants.

The folk of Turmish venerate deities who are often related to various aspect of Nature. Great rural temples and garden-monasteries are established in honour of these gods, and dancing is an important aspect of their veneration.
The isolated lands of Thindol and the Tashalar have their own group of gods, reflecting the dangerous lands they live in.

The Dead Three are a collective of the deities Bane, Bhaal and Myrkul. Together with some lesser powers they urge their followers to dominate all through terror, murder and the pursuit of power.

People of the Realms who are desperate or unscrupulous often to turn to the worship of deities related to shadows, loss and misfortune, the most powerful of which is Shar. These gods usually do not care for the well-being of their faithful, instead pursuing a more transactional or domineering relationship between god and follower.

[Root.GhaunadaurLoc] is the god of abominations, outcasts, oozes, slimes and the False. It is an ancient and unpredictable deity that requires blind obedience and constant sacrifices, though it usually rewards devotion richly. Its church is utterly disorganized, dominated at each moment by the strongest individual present.

Loviatar is the goddess of agony and pain, and in certain regions is worshipped exclusively. Her faith extols that life is incomplete without suffering, and only by exploring the full range of sensations, positive and negative, can one truly grow as a person.

The Demon Princes of the Abyss are not really gods, but still are worshipped as if they were and can even grant boons to their followers. They hate each other as much as they hate the rest of all creation, their only common goal being to draw the entire multiverse into the Abyss.
